data.title: Cannot open Code when an instance with admin rights is running
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Win 10.0 (build 10240)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an instance of VSCode with Admin privileges 
2. Go to any folder, right click and choose "Open with Code" 

**Actual**: a new instance of VSCode fails to open (or one does open but crashes instantly)
**Expected**: a new instance of VSCode with the folder open

data.title: Editor not repainted when resizing the window while a deletion confirmation dialog is opened

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

**Description:**

When a confirmation dialog is open and the editor window is resized, the window doesn't repaint itself to fit the new window dimensions. 

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open a file that is visible in the explorer. 
2. Delete the file (a confirmation dialog opens).
3. Resize the editor window.

**Screencast:**

![vsc-bug-report-screencast](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9062294/16833752/e75f0fa4-49b0-11e6-80c1-93faf5cecbdf.gif)

data.title: Hint at incorrect integrated terminal shell path if the process crashes immediately after launching

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install vscode outside windows installation drive
2. Switch terminal from `cmd` to `powershell` using `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "\\windows\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe"` in `settings.json` file.

Terminal opens and then crashes with a console.error message
`console.error('Integrated terminal exited with code ' + exitCode);`
##### Suggestion

The above error message could be improved to give the user an hint  to use absolute path to `powershell` in `settings.json` or vscode could ask for the windows installation directory on first start.
#### Fix for using powershell

Use absolute path to powershell in `settings.json`

Example, with windows installed in C drive
`"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\windows\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe"`

data.title: Fix task schema suppressTaskName and echoCommand defaultValue.
data.body:
`suppressTaskName` description  is confusing.

If `tasks.json` there is no tasks. `suppressTaskName` is always `true`. see:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerConfiguration.ts#L453

If `tasks.json` there is tasks. `suppressTaskName` default use global value is `false`. see:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerConfiguration.ts#L326

So I change the schema description to `only valid when there is a tasks property.`

In addition, `echoCommand` and `suppressTaskName` default value in schema is incorrect.

![4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7069719/16833106/53132e7c-49e0-11e6-9a30-dc9349de8726.png)

data.title: Fixes #7749 - Focus on CodeLens click
data.body:
Also focus & move cursor position on click of the empty (unlinked) area of a CodeLens line

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7749

I wanted to create a `const` for `codeLensWidget`, but wasn't sure where it should go. Also not sure if that is the right (best) way to tell if it is a codelens.

Let me know if anything needs updating.

Thanks!

data.title: proposal: lazy load language-specific extensions on first file that matches
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `code --version` => 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12 Beta (16A238m)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install vscode-lint extension: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint
2. start a new non-TypeScript project
3. observe the "Failed to load tslint library" error toast / snackbar

What I'm experiencing is mostly just a nuisance, but there's a question of efficiency / performance here as well. It appears that the tslint-server is started with each VSCode window, even before I've even opened a TypeScript file, even when the project does not even include any TypeScript files.

Because the tslint-server is always started, I get the toast / snackbar error "Failed to load tslint library" even in projects where it would never make sense for me to have the tslint NPM package installed. Note that I very much appreciate this message for TypeScript projects, it's very helpful in that case.

The majority of my projects use plain JavaScript, although I do hop through several TypeScript projects, too.

I'm not sure whether this is an extension-specific issue, or whether VSCode itself could be using documentSelector information from an extension to delay loading it until the first time a matching document type is encountered. /shrug

data.title: ContextMenu in Editor/Title only available with Tabs active
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Using the [newly available API](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates#_extension-authoring)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add a `menu - editor/title` entry to `package.json`

``` json
    "menus": {
        "editor/title": [
            {
                "command": "bookmarks.list",
                "group": "bookmarks"
            }
        ]
     }
```
1. Turn off showTabs (`"workbench.editor.showTabs": false`)

The new context menu command is not available. But if you turn on showTabs (`"workbench.editor.showTabs": true`), the command appears.

Thanks in advance

data.title: Unable to interact with Extensions list using touchscreen
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14372

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the Extensions sidebar
2. Populate the search box with search criteria (such as '@popular')
   3, Attempt to tap or scroll the results that appear in the extension sidebar

Expected result:
Items should scroll when interacted with, and when an item is tapped the right side should show details

Actual results:
Items do not scroll and tapping doesn't produce any results,
However the small "Enable" button does work.

data.title: Collect telemetry for #55
Sluggish Powershell Terminal Behavior

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\Users\Eric\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\vscode-startup.cmd"
where **vscode-startup.cmd** only contains `C:\\Windows\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted`

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Start terminal
2.Profile loads normally
3.Type Get-ChildItem (input buffer lags behind keyboard strokes)
4.Press enter after command line catches up
5.Directory listing contents lags on outputting the content as well

data.title: Clicking a stack frame with no source causes its line number to disappear
Formatting does not work with Javascript files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Example: Create an if statement, don't indent the code inside of the statement.
2. Press alt+shift+f to format, as usual. Nothing happens. This does not occur with HTML files, they format as usual.

Edit: Bug was extremely odd, currently unable to reproduce. Fixed by directly selecting JavaScript as the file's language, after searching for it. Now, in auto-detect mode it works.

data.title: Cursor does not align to indent when clicking empty line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1
- OS Version: OSX

Example:

```
void foo()
{
    bar();
    | <-- cursor should be here on click.
|<-- Not here.
}
```

Clicking under 'bar()' should align cursor to the beginning of the word 'bar', not to the left of the document, regardless of whether there are actually tab characters there or not. Also, hitting 'enter' with the cursor to the right of bar() should insert a new empty line under bar(). Only when something is actually typed, should tabs be inserted.

data.title: Visual Studio Code cannot find runtime 'node' on PATH
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install node V4.4.2
2. install VSCode 1.3.0
3. configure launch.json
4. press F5 to launch project
5. it shows Error: cannot find runtime 'node' on PATH.

The node is set correctly on System variable PATH. Also node is working under the project folder. 
The launch.json is configured as follows:
![not_found_path](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7919511/16819686/720897d8-4902-11e6-8981-fa9c7aa87574.jpg)

It worked fine before, but suddenly broken. Tried to reinstall Visual Studio Code and Node, but not working

data.title: debugAdapter Package.json does not respect OSType when nesting InitialConfigurations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04, OSX El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

we have a block:

```
    "initialConfigurations": [
      {
        "name": "C++ Launch",
        "type": "cppdbg",
        "request": "launch",
        "targetArchitecture": "x64",
        "program": "enter program name, for example ${workspaceRoot}/a.out",
        "args": [],
        "stopAtEntry": false,
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "environment": [],
        "externalConsole": true
      }]
```

that we want to override with this block on osx:

"osx": {
           "initialConfigurations": [
              {
                "name": "C++ Launch",
                "type": "cppdbg",
                "request": "launch",
                "targetArchitecture": "x64",
                **"MIMode": "lldb",**
                "program": "enter program name, for example ${workspaceRoot}/a.out",
                "args": [],
                "stopAtEntry": false,
                "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
                "environment": [],
                "externalConsole": true
              }]}
on OSX, i'm still getting the top block.

data.title: Windows Explorer shows File type as Visual Studio Code for Files Set to Open with VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro Build 10586.420

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set VSCode as default application to open with raw text file of yet-unknown file type (e.g. README.md has unknown .md file type; set README.md to Open With VSCode - and default VSCode to open all files of .md file type)
2. View file in Windows Explorer and under "Type" column, shows "Type" as Visual Studio Code.

The file shown should display whatever the file-type/extension is; in the example given above, should display MD File or perhaps even Markdown as file type as it does if set to open with any other text editor like Sublime.
